review.title: Sequential Complexity as a Descriptor for Musical Similarity
review.abstract: We propose string compressibility as a descriptor of temporal structure in audio, for the purpose of determining musical similarity. Our descriptors are based on computing track-wise compression rates of quantised audio features, using multiple temporal resolutions and quantisation granularities.

metadata.title: Sequential Complexity as a Descriptor for Musical Similarity

sections.text: However, we are engaged in the task of quantifying musical similarity, which has received considerable interest in the field of audio-based music content analysis. Due to the prevalence of music in digital formats and the expansion of web-based music databases, there is an impetus to develop new search, navigation and recommendation systems. Music content analysis has found application in such information systems as an alternative to manual annotation processes when they are unfeasible, unavailable or collectable to be supplemented. [3] We can distinguish between music content analysis applications such as audio fingerprinting [4], version identification [5], genre classification [6] and mood identification [7]. Given a query track, audio fingering should typically identify a unique track that is considered similar in relation to a collection.

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND
sections.text: For a detailed review of the recent literature on methods for determining musical similarity, from the perspective of classification, we refer to the work of Fu et al. [2] To determine musical similarity, a possible approach is used, which involves calculating pairwise distances between tracks. [2] A second approach is to apply track-wise descriptors directly to classification. [3] One possible approach involves calculating distances which are then used for classification. [4] A first and second approach is to apply track-wise characteristics to spectral characteristics, including MFCCs, to perform genre-classification using the closest neighbours (KNN). (GMMs) are estimated on each target class. Li and Ogihara [12] propose to classify histograms using GMMs and KNN for genre classification and mood classification.

sections.heading: III. APPROACH
sections.text: Suppose we are given the audio feature vector sequence V = (v1,.., vT). Similar to the descriptor proposed in [46], where C (V, λ) denotes the number of bits required to represent V, we therefore calculate the compression rate Rλ (V), Rλ (V) = C (V, λ) T (2), where C (V, λ) denotes the number of bits required to represent V, given a quantification scheme with λ levels and using a specific sequential compression scheme. In order to obtain a longitudinal invariant measure of sequential complexity, we normalize sequence length-length-T. Given the ith sequence sequence sequence contained in our collection, we calculate compression rates for feature sequences extracted from musical audio. We refer to the set of compression rates as a feature sequence sequence sequence sequence sequence sequence sequence sequence CDCDsequencers (sequence sequence sequence sequence CDCDsequencers, CDsequence sequence sequencers)

sections.heading: A. Similarity rating prediction
sections.text: We assume that the paired distance between the descriptors correlates with the similarity evaluation associated with the pairs of tracks. To predict similarity evaluation, we use paired distances between descriptor vectors as a feature and apply multinomial regression. We use ri, n to denote the ninth descriptor vector calculated for the tracks in our collection with 1 ≤ n ≤ N and a set of available descriptor vectors. We calculate separate descriptor vectors across audio characteristics and across FCD resolutions, with each vector component in ri corresponding to a quantization granularity. We use d < i, j > to denote the distances between ri, n, rj, n, n that are achieved across all N descriptor vectors, with each vector component in ri corresponding to a quantization granularity.

sections.heading: B. Song year prediction
sections.text: In the following [10] we apply a linear regression model. In view of the ith track in our collection, we forecast the associated chart entry date yi using a linear combination of components in the descriptor vectors ri, n, y, i = N ² n = 1 PhenomenTnri, n + α (4), with θn regression coefficients for the ninth descriptor vector specifying how to predict similarity and where α denotes the intersection of the model. We describe our model estimation method for predicting the song year in section IV-B1. We encourage the use of both multinomial and linear regression techniques as a simple means of evaluating the use of FCDs to determine similarity based on metric space. We perform our evaluation by taking into account predictable accuracy and interpreting estimated coefficients as characteristics.

sections.heading: IV. EVALUATION
sections.text: In fact, it is so that most people are able to understand themselves and to understand how they have behaved. (...) In fact, it is so that most people are able to understand themselves. (...) It is not so that they feel able to identify themselves. (...) It is not so that they do. (...) It is as if they do. (...) sections.heading: A. Similarity rating prediction
sections.text: We evaluate similarity ratings based on comments we have collected for a subset of the charts (1). Prior to our research, we received a total of 7,784 pairs of similarity ratings from 456 subjects who participated in a web-based listening test3. Subjects were asked to quantify a pair of musical similarities between consecutive splint extracts, omitting any training step from the evaluation process. Note that while we require that paired similarity ratings be performed on a five-point scale, we do not assume that similarities are assessed on an absolute scale that they use to perform evaluations. Given three splint pairs for which we have appropriate ratings (4, 5), we consider the evaluations quantitative similarities quantitative quantitative.

sections.heading: B. Song year prediction
sections.text: We assume that we use the entry data as our annotation data and apply the linear regression model used in (4). Figure 5 shows a histogram of chart entry data. We use the aforementioned filtering method to control the potential cover versions and album effects, in addition to the analog effects at the artist level. The resulting training and test datasets consist of 10 728 and 4 745 tracks. We deem them outliers in the training data that go beyond the 99th percentile. We replace such outliers with implied values.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that the case is a case in which it is a case in which it is a crime, in which it is a crime.

sections.heading: VI. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: This work benefited from advice and commentary from Andrew J. R. Simpson, Dan Stowell, Anssi Klapuri, Mark D. Plumbley and Armand Leroi.

referenceMentions.context: We are concerned with the task of quantifying musical similarity, which has received considerable interest in the field of audio-based music content analysis [1], [2].
We are concerned with the task of quantifying musical similarity, which has received considerable interest in the field of audio-based music content analysis [1], [2].

Music content analysis has found application in such information retrieval systems as an alternative to manual annotation processes, when the latter are infeasible, unavailable or amenable to be supplemented [3].
We may distinguish between music content analysis applications such as audio fingerprinting [4], version identification [5], genre classification [6] and mood identification [7].
We may distinguish between music content analysis applications such as audio fingerprinting [4], version identification [5], genre classification [6] and mood identification [7].
We may distinguish between music content analysis applications such as audio fingerprinting [4], version identification [5], genre classification [6] and mood identification [7].
We may distinguish between music content analysis applications such as audio fingerprinting [4], version identification [5], genre classification [6] and mood identification [7].
Thus, we may distinguish between music classification tasks according to the degree of specificity associated with the measure of musical similarity [1].
Descriptors may be characterised according to how temporal structure is accounted for [2].
We may distinguish between bag-of-features representations [8], which discard information on temporal structure, and sequential representations.
Whereas song year prediction has received little attention in the literature, the song year is important in determining musical preference [9].
Thus, song year prediction might be applied in music recommendation [10].

Based on the second approach, Tzanetakis and Cook [11] compute first and second-order moments on spectral features including MFCCs, to perform genre classification using the k-nearest neighbours (KNN) algorithm and Gaussian mixture models (GMMs) estimated on each target class.
Li and Ogihara [12] propose to classify Daubechies wavelet histograms using GMMs and KNN for genre and mood classification.
[13] propose methods for learning similarity functions based on constructing decision trees for genre classification.
[14] propose feature transformations based on supervised learning and using onset and loudness features, for the purpose of album and artist classification.
Based on the approach of determining distances between descriptors, Logan and Salomon [15] propose to estimate GMMs on individual tracks.
Aucouturier and Pachet [16] in contrast compute cross-likelihoods between GMMs using Monte Carlo approximations for the purpose of genre classification, whereas Berenzweig et al.
[17] consider the asymptotic likelihood approximation of the KLD and centroid distances for the task of similarity rating prediction.
Mandel and Ellis [18] instead represent tracks as single Gaussians and use (1) as a distance measure between track pairs.

An alternative approach to computing the KLD is based on computing histograms of quantised features, as proposed by Vignoli and Pauws [19] for playlist recommendation; Levy and Sandler [20] compare approaches in the context of genre classification.

An alternative approach to computing the KLD is based on computing histograms of quantised features, as proposed by Vignoli and Pauws [19] for playlist recommendation; Levy and Sandler [20] compare approaches in the context of genre classification.
Aucouturier and Pachet [8] argue that the bag-of-features approach is insufficient to model polyphonic music for determining similarity.
Sequential representations based on mid-level features are widely applied for the purpose of version identification [5].
Tzanetakis and Cook [11] propose to estimate the local mean and variance of features contained in a 1s window.
[22] apply a single, global summarisation step to overlapping windows, computing variance and percentiles.
[23], Hamel et al.
[24], Wülfing and Riedmiller [25].
[24], Wülfing and Riedmiller [25].
Pampalk [26] proposes fluctuation patterns describing loudness modulation across frequency bands, whereas Lee et al.
[27] propose statistics based on modulation spectral analysis.
[23] consider a variety of statistics based on spectral analysis and autocorrelation.
[28], Coviello et al.
[29] apply multivariate autoregressive modelling to windowed features, for the tasks of genre and tag classification.
For genre classification, Li and Sleep [30] propose an SVM kernel in which pairwise distances are obtained by comparing dictionaries generated using the Lempel-Ziv compression algorithm [31].
For genre classification, Li and Sleep [30] propose an SVM kernel in which pairwise distances are obtained by comparing dictionaries generated using the Lempel-Ziv compression algorithm [31].

Reed and Lee [32] apply latent semantic analysis to unigram and bigram counts for classification using SVMs, whereas Langlois and Marques [33] propose to estimate language models for computing sequence cross-likelihoods for genre and artist classification.

Reed and Lee [32] apply latent semantic analysis to unigram and bigram counts for classification using SVMs, whereas Langlois and Marques [33] propose to estimate language models for computing sequence cross-likelihoods for genre and artist classification.
Ren and Jang [34] propose an algorithm for computing histograms of feature codeword sequences for genre classification.
[35] propose an ensemble of classifiers, where each classifier is trained on features at a given time scale.
Dieleman and Schrauwen [36] apply feature learning based on spherical K-means clustering to tag classification.
Although not applied to classification, Mauch and Levy [37] propose a similar smoothing approach for characterising structural change at multiple time scales.
[38] propose deep learning architectures for genre, artist and key classification tasks.
[24] propose a deep learning architecture incorporating multiple feature aggregation functions for tag classification.
The approach proposed in this work resembles methods applying statistical models to quantised feature sequences [30], [32]–[34].
The approach proposed in this work resembles methods applying statistical models to quantised feature sequences [30], [32]–[34].
The approach proposed in this work resembles methods applying statistical models to quantised feature sequences [30], [32]–[34].

Since the obtained statistics may be compared using a metric, our approach has the potential to be combined with indexing and hashing schemes for computationally efficient retrieval [39]– [41], while retaining information on temporal structure.

For each track excerpt in the dataset, we extract a set of 25 audio features, using MIRToolbox [47] version 1.

Feature name Description Chroma (Ellis and Poliner) 12-component chromagram based on using phase-derivatives to identify tonal components in spectrum [48].
roughness Average roughness [49] between peak pairs in magnitude spectrum.
irregularity Squared amplitude difference between successive partials [50].

We compress symbol sequences using the prediction by partial match (PPM) algorithm2, described in [55].

We consider PPM a general-purpose string compression algorithm which may be substituted with an alternative compressor; in initial experiments we obtained similar results using Lempel-Ziv compression [31].
Nevertheless, we note that PPM compresses efficiently compared to alternative compression schemes [55].
Note however that we make no claim that FCDs capture any notion of musical complexity as proposed in [56].
For human similarity judgements, two issues prompt consideration: In addition to music being inherently subjective [57], human similarity judgements are context-dependent [58], [59].

We contend that for music content analysis based on an ensemble of systems as proposed in [61], the entire target set of predicted musical similarity might be used when forming recommendations.

In contrast, for track recommendation relying on predicted similarity alone, when forming recommendations, it is typically of interest to consider tracks deemed similar to a query, while disregarding tracks deemed dissimilar [62].

2) Performance statistics: To quantify the accuracy of similarity rating prediction, as discussed in [68] we compute Kendall’s τb and Spearman’s ρs, both which are ordinal measures of association between predicted and annotated similarity ratings.
Thus, in the presence of ties τb may be viewed as a more appropriate means of comparing ordinal sequences [69].

We interpret these observations as evidence for a non-trivial, trend-exhibiting process governing observed descriptor values [75].
Our proposed descriptors are computed in an unsupervised manner and may be implemented efficiently, requiring O(n) time complexity for each track [76].

Since our descriptors may be computed off-line or incrementally and thereafter combined with indexing methods as proposed in [39]–[41], we deem them potentially applicable in large-scale content retrieval systems.

Similar to results obtained in [24], [35], [36], [77], our results using sequential complexity descriptors suggest that an approach based on multiple temporal resolutions is advantageous for determining musical similarity.

We acknowledge that in both cases, audio production may confound the association between similarity measures and respective outcome variables, as observed in [60].
For future work, we aim to measure the degree of confounding by introducing suitable audio degradations [78].

metadata.abstractText: We propose string compressibility as a descriptor of temporal structure in audio, for the purpose of determining musical similarity. Our descriptors are based on computing track-wise compression rates of quantised audio features, using multiple temporal resolutions and quantisation granularities. To verify that our descriptors capture musically relevant information, we incorporate our descriptors into similarity rating prediction and song year prediction tasks. We base our evaluation on a dataset of 15 500 track excerpts of Western popular music, for which we obtain 7 800 web-sourced pairwise similarity ratings. To assess the agreement among similarity ratings, we perform an evaluation under controlled conditions, obtaining a rank correlation of 0.33 between intersected sets of ratings. Combined with bag-offeatures descriptors, we obtain performance gains of 31.1% and 10.9% for similarity rating prediction and song year prediction. For both tasks, analysis of selected descriptors reveals that representing features at multiple time scales benefits prediction accuracy.
